title: 114_s1990
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Computer Security Act". It includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "Federal Computer Security Act," defines key terms related to agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms related to agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls, which include information known to the user, an access device provided to the user, and a unique biometric characteristic of the user. SEC. 3. INSPECTOR GENERAL REPORT ON FEDERAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS. Inspector Generals of covered agencies must submit a report to the Comptroller General and relevant committees within 240 days of this Act, detailing information on Federal computer systems. The report should include descriptions of logical access standards used by the agencies. The covered agency must provide a description of the logical access standards used to access Federal computer systems containing classified or personally identifiable information, including a list and description of access controls and whether multi-factor controls are used. The covered agency must describe the data security management practices, including software inventories and associated licenses on Federal computer systems. The covered agency must provide details on software security controls, including data loss prevention and digital rights management software, and describe how they are being used. The covered agency must describe its policies for ensuring entities implement data security practices, including contractors. The report may be based on audits, evaluations, or reports. The report submitted by the covered agency must be based on audits, evaluations, or reports related to its programs or practices. It should be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex, and will be made available to any Member of Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but will be in unclassified form.
